Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement under citizenship law
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in finding the Respondent satisfied the residency requirement despite only 277 days of physical presence
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for 277 days
Maintained strong family ties in Canada
Financially dependent on parents in Canada
Defendant_Behavior: Absences from Canada due to studies abroad, but maintained centralized mode of living in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under s. 22(1) of the Citizenship Act
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; evidence accepted as credible
Evidence_Used: Proof of family residence in Canada
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act – residency requirement (1095 days), with allowance for absences under 'centralized mode of living'
Application_Basis: Residency calculation including temporary absences for education
Evidence_Assessed: Intent to maintain Canada as primary residence
Relief_Sought: Overturn of citizenship approval based on residency deficiency
Governing_Rule: 1095-day residency requirement with exceptions for temporary absences tied to a centralized mode of living
Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found by the Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; citizenship application upheld
Harm_Assessment: No harm established; public interest in proper application of citizenship law addressed
Cause_Description: Challenge to citizenship grant based on alleged failure to meet physical residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Evidence evaluated under reasonableness standard; deference given to Citizenship Judge
Legal_Provision_Violated: Alleged violation of residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Issues: No significant disputes over authenticity or admissibility of evidence
Residency_Compliance: Found compliant via 'centralized mode of living' despite low physical presence
Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – no allegation of false information
Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act, s. 22(1) – Judicial review of citizenship decisions
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Supportive of temporary absences and ongoing connection to Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Respondent’s absences were temporary and consistent with a centralized mode of living in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of living test for assessing residency
